awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Functional Dissection of Ubiquitination Signaling by Quantitative Chemical Proteomics
awd_abstract_narration:
With this award, the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Chemistry Division is funding Dr. Yue Chen from the University of Minnesota to investigate a specific cellular signaling pathway using an innovative new methodology called, quanititative chemical proteomics. Ubiquitination is a modification of proteins with a number of biological functions including signaling. For example, when DNA is damaged, ubiquitination plays a critical role in activating specific response pathways to initiate DNA damage repair.  A newly developed quantitative chemical proteomics approach is  applied to reveal just how this takes place. Experimental studies are expected to identify novel ubiquitination-dependent regulatory mechanisms and find previously unknown enzymatic activities in DNA damage response. During the project, undergraduate biochemistry students train with interdisciplinary techniques in chemical synthesis and quantitative proteomics through a fully integrated chemical proteomic training program. Additional outreach programs promote biochemistry education for high school students through specifically designed field learning activities.

The research projects integrate the new isotope-encoded stoichiometry analysis method and chemical proteomics strategies to functionally dissect ubiquitination signaling pathways. Compared to the traditional relative quantification, this approach enables site-specific absolute quantification of ubiquitination prevalence and, therefore, allows the identification of ubiquitination targets that are stoichiometrically activated in specific biological processes. This strategy is applied to determine the dynamic activation of ubiquitination signaling during DNA double-strand break. Temporal dynamics analysis and functional validation reveal key regulatory ubiquitination targets that are critical for the activation of specific response pathways. In vitro and in vivo quantitative analysis determine the substrate dynamics and specificities of important ubiquitination E3 ligases in double-strand break and repair. Overall, these studies provide mechanistic insights into the ubiquitination-mediated signaling and regulatory pathways in DNA damage and response.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merits: Ubiquitination (Ub) is an essential regulatory protein posttranslational modification that governs diverse cellular pathways in eukaryotes including protein homeostasis, cellular signaling, protein-protein interaction and epigenetic programming. Classic strategies in proteomic analysis of ubiquitination pathways with affinity enrichment and relative quantification analysis are limited in understanding the physiological significance of ubiquitination dynamics as well as upstream regulatory enzyme activities. Through the support of this NSF Award, we made major contributions to the proteomic characterization of ubiquitination pathways in the following aspects.

First, we developed a chemical proteomics strategy called Isotope-Balanced Absolute Quantification of Ubiquitination (IBAQ-Ub) for absolute quantification of ubiquitination stoichiometry. Compared to the classic relative quantification approach that compares the relative changes, stoichiometry analysis provides physiological relevance of ubiquitination dynamics. For example, a two-fold relative increase can mean a stoichiometry increase from 0.1% to 0.3% or 30% to 90%, which apparently indicates different physiological relevance of ubiquitination dynamics. In our published study (Li, Y. Angew Chimie Intl 2019), we demonstrated the reliability and broad applicability of IBAQ-Ub on site-specific measurement of absolute ubiquitination stoichiometry with a wide dynamic range using spike-in standards or complex nuclear extracts. We demonstrated, for the first time, that ubiquitination has a relatively low stoichiometry overall with key histone H2B K117/K120 ubiquitination less than 1%.

Second, we improved and applied the IBAQ-Ub for functional proteomic analysis of ubiquitination dynamics. In our published study (Nelson, S. JACS 2023), through the collaboration with Deshmukh lab at UCSD, we analyzed the stoichiometries of monoubiquitinated proteins with IBAQ-Ub and identified major monoubiquitination target sites. We continued to improve the IBAQ-Ub by developing one-step IBAQ-Ub which significantly simplified the labeling and analysis workflow (manuscript in preparation). We further developed a software tool for reliable calculation of site-specific stoichiometry using IBAQ-Ub approaches. We demonstrated that the improved strategy offers similar accuracy and reliability as the original IBAQ-Ub. Application of the strategy characterized ubiquitination target sites and linkage dynamics in RNF168-mediated enzymatic reaction and identified stoichiometric constraints of ubiquitination signaling in DNA replication stress and damage response.

Thirdly, we developed a bioinformatic strategy for system-wide profiling ubiquitin E3 ligase activities. E3 ligases are major regulators in ubiquitination pathways to recognize and interact with the Ub targets for enzymatic reactions. We developed Ubiquitination E3 ligase Activity Profiling Analysis (UbE3-APA), for system-wide analysis of E3 ligase activity based on quantitative proteomic data (Gong, Y. Bioinformatics 2022). We demonstrated that the strategy was reliable in specifying E3 ligase activities with the published study using enzyme knockout models. We further demonstrated its broad applicability in profiling E3 ligase activities in cellular stress response and in analyzing both data-dependent or data-independent mass spectrometry studies. Lastly, we applied the strategy with the stoichiometry dynamics generated by one-step IBAQ-Ub analysis and identified E3 ligase activities changes upon DNA replication stress and damage response.

Broader Impacts: My long-term educational goal is to promote equitable learning opportunities for minority biochemistry students in college while integrating education with our chemical proteomics research program to promote training and scientific literacy of biochemistry in health and environment. Through this NSF Award, we have made significant contribution to achieve these learning objectives in the following three aspects.

First, I developed an activity-based learning practice to promote advanced-level biochemistry education. Since 2017, in collaboration with Professor Timothy Griffin, co-instructor of BIOC4331 (structure, catalysis and metabolism), we have implemented study group-based activity learning practices including in-class exercises and extracurricular study group exercises to promote peer interaction and learning. Comparing course grades of students participating or non-participating in our study group activities, we demonstrated that our practices significantly improved student academic performances. Surveys at the end of each semester showed consistent strong appreciation from students on our study group activities to promote student’s interests and learning experiences in biochemistry.

Second, I developed a chemical proteomic training program to promote chemical and quantitative proteomics training. This program involved undergraduate students from biochemistry, chemistry or physics majors with strong interests in learning proteomics. Students received weekly reading guidance and participated in weekly group discussions on guided questions. In the past five years, we had over 30 students participated in this program and most of them continued their studies in the STEM field. At least four students became co-authors of manuscripts.

Thirdly, I have participated in various outreach activities to promote scientific learning and education. I served as environ-mentor for local high school students in collaboration with Great River Greening. Invited by the American Chemical Society, we published an ebook called Functional Proteomics (DOI: 10.1021/acsinfocus.7e5010) to introduce functional proteomics technologies for students or faculties from different fields to learn cutting edge methodologies and applications. We have also contributed a book chapter to the Methods in Molecular Biology book series on Activity Proteomics describing our Ub E3 ligase activity profiling analysis.


Last Modified: 06/26/2024
Modified by: Yue Chen
